properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Moist southeasterly winds blowing off of Hudson Bay continue in the Coral Harbour area, creating fog, especially in the overnight and morning hours. Visibilities should improve somewhat Thursday afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T00:06:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T08:07:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2020650663.2019
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow possible for eastern slopes of the Coast Mountains Friday and Friday night. As a cold airmass settles in over the BC Interior tonight an upper level disturbance will approach from the north, stalling over southern BC through the weekend. As freezing levels drop, rain showers mixed at times with wet flurries are forecast tonight. A persistent northeasterly flow will set-up later Friday and areas over the western and southern Chilcotin could potentially see snowfall accumulations beginning Friday afternoon. Snowfall accumulations remain quite uncertain at this time, but 5 to 10 cm of snow by Saturday morning is in the realm of possibilities. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T13:07:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T21:08:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2991376889.2019
Area: Chilcotin
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wet snow likely near the Rocky Mountains tonight and Friday. A cooler airmass is settling in over northeastern BC this morning and is expected to remain in place through the weekend. A slow moving disturbance will continue to give periods of rain mixed at times with wet snow into Friday. Portions of Highway 97 near the Rocky Mountains will likely see snowfall accumulations tonight. Areas along the highway west of Fort Nelson leading into Tetsa River National Park and south near Buckinghorse River and Sikanni Chief could see 5 to 10 cm of wet snow tonight. Further south in the Peace River region, pockets of wet snow have been reported this morning. The potential for rain mixed at times with wet snow will linger into Friday afternoon. A few centimetres of wet snow is possible today through Friday over the Peace River District, as well as Highway 97 and the Pine Pass west of Chetwynd. Cooler but drier conditions will prevail through the weekend with a return to near seasonal values early next week. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T08:18:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T16:19:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3526947156.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Isolated thunderstorms producing small hail and gusty winds late this afternoon. Isolated thunderstorms, capable of producing wind gusts to 70 or 80 km/h and pea sized hail, will move through the region late this afternoon and into the early evening hours. Environment Canada meteorologists will continue to monitor these thunderstorms closely. Note that Environment Canada's severe thunderstorm warning criteria are 2 cm hail, wind gusts to 90 km/h, and 50 mm of rain in an hour or less. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T03:44:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T20:31:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0866600049.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures across central and northern Alberta are expected to fall below freezing tonight, leading to widespread frost. Residual rain showers and cloud cover may protect some areas, but Friday is expected to have a cold start none-the-less. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T13:39:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T21:40:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1660886837.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wet snow likely near the Rocky Mountains tonight and Friday. A cooler airmass is settling in over northeastern BC this morning and is expected to remain in place through the weekend. A slow moving disturbance will continue to give periods of rain mixed at times with wet snow into Friday. Portions of Highway 97 near the Rocky Mountains will likely see snowfall accumulations tonight. Areas along the highway west of Fort Nelson leading into Tetsa River National Park and south near Buckinghorse River and Sikanni Chief could see 5 to 10 cm of wet snow tonight. Further south in the Peace River region, pockets of wet snow have been reported this morning. The potential for rain mixed at times with wet snow will linger into Friday afternoon. A few centimetres of wet snow is possible today through Friday over the Peace River District, as well as Highway 97 and the Pine Pass west of Chetwynd. Cooler but drier conditions will prevail through the weekend with a return to near seasonal values early next week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T08:18:40-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong north winds continue today at Baker Lake due to an intense low pressure system over Hudson Bay. These winds will strengthen a bit more late tonight to around 70 gusting 90 km/h, and these very strong northerlies will persist most of the day on Friday. Winds will diminish slightly Friday night and continue to slowly diminish on Saturday as the low finally starts to weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T11:35:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T19:36:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2230219948.2019
Area: Baker Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Skies will partially clear tonight under a cool ridge of high pressure. As a result, temperatures are expected to dip below the zero mark over the northern grainbelt. Elsewhere there should be enough cloud to keep temperatures above freezing. On Friday night, frost will be widespread across all of southern Saskatchewan as the high pressure ridge builds southward. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T13:24:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T21:25:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0606724669.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long duration snowfall event starting the afternoon of Friday September 27 through Monday September 30 is anticipated for parts of southwestern Alberta as a moisture laden Pacific weather system tracks through the area. There is still uncertainty around snowfall accumulations as warm surface temperatures will melt initial snowfall. Current indications suggest that by Monday, total accumulations of 15 to 30 cm over portions of southwestern Alberta are possible. For the extreme southwest corner of the province, upslope flow will enhance snowfall along higher terrain with localized snowfall totals of over 50 cm possible by Monday. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T13:23:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T21:24:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3469390789.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An approaching weather system will bring significant snowfall to the eastern Kitikmeot. Snowfall will begin in Taloyoak on Friday morning and over Gjoa Haven near mid day. Snowfall totals for Taloyoak will be near 10 cm before the snow tapers off on Friday evening. Snowfall amounts for Gjoa Haven could reach near 20 cm before ending on Saturday morning. Gusty northerly winds over Gjoa Haven on Friday may also give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T11:21:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T19:22:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1038805159.2019
Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A cool airmass has settled over northeastern BC this morning. A slow moving disturbance will begin to produce snow over the Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park region late today and into tonight. 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall over eastern sections of the region near Tetsa River by Friday morning. Western sections will see lighter accumulations of a few centimetres. The snow will taper off Friday morning as the disturbance moves southward. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-27T09:40:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T17:41:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2055880627.2019
Area: Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Skies will partially clear tonight under a cool ridge of high pressure. As a result, temperatures are expected to dip below the zero mark over portions of west-central Manitoba. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
